title: Boris Johnson says best way to honor Jo Cox is to deliver Brexit
text:
U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson | Ben Stansall/AFP via Getty Images Boris Johnson says best way to honor Jo Cox is to deliver Brexit British prime minister branded ‘a disgrace’ for comment about murdered MP.

Boris Johnson faced a barrage of criticism on Wednesday evening when he said the best way to honor the memory of Jo Cox was to deliver Brexit.

Labour MP Cox was murdered by a right-wing extremist in June 2016, just before the EU referendum vote. Her killer, Thomas Mair, shouted "Britain First" — the name of a far-right group — as he carried out the attack.

In the House of Commons on Wednesday, Tracy Brabin, who was elected in Cox's constituency in Yorkshire after the murder, urged the prime minister to moderate his language "so that we will all feel secure when we're going about our jobs."

Johnson replied that "the best way to honor the memory of Jo Cox and indeed the best way to bring this country together would be, I think, to get Brexit done."

The prime minister also told Labour's Paula Sheriff, who called on him to stop using language such as “surrender,” “traitor” and “betrayal” in relation to Brexit, that he had "never heard such humbug in all my life.”

Johnson was speaking during an often bad-tempered debate in the House of Commons the day after Supreme Court judges ruled that his suspension of parliament was "unlawful."

The prime minister was roundly condemned for his words. Cox's husband Brendan said on Twitter he felt "a bit sick at Jo's name being used in this way."

Feel a bit sick at Jo’s name being used in this way. The best way to honour Jo is for all of us (no matter our views) to stand up for what we believe in, passionately and with determination. But never to demonise the other side and always hold onto what we have in common. — Brendan Cox (@MrBrendanCox) September 25, 2019

Jo Swinson, leader of the Liberal Democrats, said Johnson was "a disgrace" for his comments while Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said there was "a gaping moral vacuum where the office of prime minister used to be."
description: British prime minister branded ‘a disgrace’ for comment about murdered MP.
